awd_titl_txt: NMR Studies of Nematicity in Strongly Correlated Electron Systems under Uniaxial Strain
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract: In high temperature superconductors an electronic state with zero resistance emerges at low temperatures.  Superconductivity is a quantum mechanical phenomenon that has a wide range of potential applications, including magnetic levitation and energy transport without dissipation, capable of changing the society and economy in a transformative way. But superconductivity is still poorly understood and is seen in various types of materials.  A particularly interesting case occurs for nematic materials, in which the electronic behavior spontaneously becomes anisotropic. This behavior can be induced in the laboratory by applying strain to the crystal, which may alter its physical properties. We aim to investigate the microscopic behavior using magnetic resonance to study the electronic response to strain.  This project will support the education of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as a broad audience of senior citizens via a new course on quantum mechanics without equations for the public through the university extension office.  

Technical Abstract: The objective of this project is to develop a fundamental understanding of quantum critical nematic fluctuations in strongly correlated electron materials. Electronic nematic order has been observed in the iron and cuprate superconductors, and evidence suggests that nematic fluctuations may be responsible for the superconducting pairing mechanism and the non-Fermi liquid behavior at optimal doping in these materials. However, the presence of multiple types of order parameters and their fluctuations complicate the interpretation of experiments and preclude the identification of the essential physics behind these phenomena. Recent evidence suggests that electronic nematic fluctuations may be responsible for superconductivity in some cases. However, multiple types of electronic order parameters can be present simultaneously, and by their very nature strongly correlated systems are highly sensitive to impurities, giving rise to microscopic inhomogeneity that obfuscates experimental observations. As a result, there is no clear picture as to what extent electron nematicity is central to the fundamental physics of high temperature superconductivity in the iron and cuprates materials, or whether it is simply a curious epiphenomenon. This project will answer this question through nuclear magnetic resonance studies of cuprates, vanadates, iridates and iron pnictide materials under uniaxial strain in regimes of phase space that have never been investigated. These investigations will disentangle the roles of disorder, nematicity, and antiferromagnetism at play in the normal state of the high temperature iron and cuprate superconductors, and will also explore new regimes of phase space using uniaxial strain as a thermodynamic tuning variable. The outcome of this project will be a more complete understanding of the role of quantum critical nematic fluctuations and the essential physics of strongly correlated electron materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the relationship between strain and long-range order of electrons in correlated electron materials.  Usually the anisotropy of the electronic response is dictated by the symmetry of the underlying crystal structure.  However, in certain cases the electronic system may spontaneously break this symmetry.  An example might be when the resistivity of a tetragonal crystal becomes different when the current flows in different in-plane directions.  This effect is known as nematic ordering or nematicity, and is thought to play an important role in driving unconventional superconductivity in certain materials.

This project used nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) as a local probe of the electronic behavior in materials that undergo nematic ordering, or are driven to be nematic through the application of uniaxial stress or strain.  One material studied was the iron-based superconductor, FeSe, where superconductivity emerges from a nematic state.  NMR measurements in the superconducting state revealed no traces of antiferromagnetism, a state that could possibly compete with the superconductivity.  Moreover, the superconducting vortex lines in this material appear to exhibit enhancements of the local density of states.

Another material investigated is TmVO4, which also spontaneously becomes nematic at low temperature. This material, however, is insulating and has no conduction electrons.  It therefore offers useful insights into nematicity in general, without the complications presented by the presence of conduction electrons.  For example, when a magnetic field is applied to this material, the nematic phase can be continuously suppressed to zero temperature at a quantum phase transition. This project studied this phenomenon, and uncovered an unexpected second order effect.

Most of the rare-earth ions are strongly magnetic, and are often used for new technologies such as earbuds and hybrid vehicles.  In some cases, such as Thulium (Tm), the ion does not couple to magnetic fields.  This is the reason that TmVO4  undergoes nematic order rather than becoming magnetic.  However, we discovered that for sufficiently high magnetic fields, this material will become magnetized, and that the nematic order itself couples to the magnetic field.

Importantly, two new approaches were developed in this project.  Because the materials used are so sensitive to magnetic fields, it is important to carefully control the shape of the sample under study.  Ideally, the sample should be either a perfect sphere or an ellipsoid. A focused ion beam was used to carefully cut the crystal into an ellipsoid. The resulting NMR spectrum exhibited a much higher spectral resolution, enabling detailed studies that would not be possible otherwise.  A second techinique developed in this project was to measure the nuclear relaxation rate at multiple spin transitions.  Traditionally, only one transition is usually studied, but measurements at multiple transitions uncovered new information about different relaxation channels.  These approaches can advance future studies of correlated electron materials with NMR.
